comments.body: Unrelated to this PR, what do you think about renaming `exercise` into `exercise_with_actors` and `exercise_without_actors` into `exercise`? The only name existing in the protobuf is `exercise` and the with/without part is controlled via the optionality of the `actors` field.
As 'exercise' is supported only by LF < 1.5, we should just kill `exercise` and rename `exercise_without_actors` into exercise.
I'm fine with that too.

comments.body: This is a nice approach, but the `ur` includes the ledger transaction, which means we aren't distinguishing between "exercise" and "exercise by key". Maybe the semantics needs to be reformulated anyway to track the transaction structure more closely, so I'm ok leaving it like this for now.

You are right, this does not make the distinction between "exercise" and "exercise by key". But currently the implementation does not neither, so it is probably fine to let the semantics like that until we introduce a new transaction format.
Let's leave it as is for now and fix it when we've introduced the new transaction format.

comments.body: This isn't necessary, since the `TyStruct` rule enforces distinct field names (`fâ‚ < â€¦ < fâ‚™ lexicographically`), and sorting would preserve the non-uniqueness of field names.

Doesn't the `TyStruct` rule only speak about _well-formed_ types? By adding this condition we make sure that this rule only applied if the resulting type is well-formed. Thus, it would transform ill-formed structural records into well-formed ones.

`TyStruct` and all the other rules in that section are what *defines* well-formed types. When we sort a badly-ordered struct into a well-ordered struct, we may still have duplicate fields. At that point, `TyStruct` will say "hey, that's not well-formed" and reject the struct.

This type normalization rules are operating on pure syntax. They make no well-formedness guarantees. E.g. `'Numeric' 'Int64'` is a possible outcome of type normalization, even though it's not well-formed.

We don't have a requirement anywhere that an expression is only well-formed if its type is well-formed, do we? Without this requirement or the condition I added here, the expression
```
< a = 1, a = 2>
```
would be well-formed but have an ill-formed type.

My understanding was that the typing rules are such that you can _prove_ that all well-formed expressions have a well-formed type rather than well-formedness of the type being a requirement. Am I mistaken here?
Ah, that sounds like a missing hypothesis in `ExpStructCon`. It should require `Ïƒ` be well-formed. (IIRC it did require this at some point before the struct-field-order PR was merged.)
Compare with `ExpVarCon` where each ` Ïƒâ‚  â†   Ïƒâ‚'` has an accompanying `Î“  âŠ¢  Ïƒâ‚' : kâ‚`, for example.
That's a good point. I'll fix the `ExpStructCon` rule then.

comments.body:
Shouldn't that refer to `fetch` rather than `exercise`?
```suggestion
     Err "Fetch of unknown contract"
```

No, it's not a mistake. Fetch errors look like exercise errors (see the other fetch error case). I don't know if this is desirable, but it's closer to the implementation. My guess is that we'll have to redo all the errors at some point (looking at the future w/ exception handling) and we can fix this then.

comments.body: Maybe use more descriptive names than `v_1` and `v_2` here?, e.g., `actors` or `acts` for `v_1`.
I like the idea but don't want to break the convention of using `v` for values, and `vâ‚` is already taken here (see EvUpdExercConsum)...
The pattern we use here of giving a grammar for `v` and then using indexed versions of `v` is very customary. Unfortunately, we can't have more complex indices like "actor" here unlike in LaTeX.

comments.body:
```suggestion
   â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” EvUpdExercChcBodyExec
```

The other rule name change are good -- I went ahead and used them (putting the `Err` at the end to make it more obvious that these are error cases).

This particular suggestion is less good, because the name `EvUpdExercConsumErr` doesn't have any ambiguity, and it draws parallels to the similar but different error that can arise out of a non-consuming choice. I'm going to leave this one as it is.

comments.body:
The comment should not be there. This log tracks semantics changes or serialization changes by version. Here we did not change the `dev` version of LF, but "fix" a bug in the spec for all version of LF.
We usually do not track bug fixes in the specification, I will do the same for this change.

diffHunk:
@@ -298,6 +298,11 @@ Version: 1.dev
 
   + **Add** generic map type ``GenMap``.
 
+  + **Change** the operational semantics to make the evaluation order of
+    sub-expressions, and memoization of values, implementation-defined.
+    This change preserves the determinism of ``Ok`` results, but makes
+    ``Err`` results non-deterministic.
+

comments.body:
Isn't this is a breaking change because we removed the (uninhabited) kind `k -> nat`? This would be a problem since DAML Engine needs to be able to load DARs which contain type abstractions of this kind.
I would suggest we keep the definition of kinds as is and add the notion of "erasable kinds" as defined above on top of that. Then one can prove that each kind `k` satisfies one of the following three:
1. `k` is erasable.
2. There are `k_1, ..., k_n` with `n >= 1` and `k = k_1 -> k2 -> ... -> k_n -> nat` and hence `k` is uninhabited and can hence be erased at runtime as well.
3. `k = nat`. This is the case where we need to demote from the type to the value level.

The problem is that the speedy compiler currently blows up if you try to apply `f` when it has kind `* -> nat`. You can introduce such variables with a forall or type lambda. This makes it an illegal kind in some ways but not others. It sounds like you want to do something else in these cases?

For example, the term `/\(f : * -> nat). ADD_NUMERIC @(f Unit)` is perfectly valid under current LF spec, but speedy will balk before it even tries to run it. 

I feel like outlawing this kind construction outright is better than giving it any sort of semantics in Speedy.

@sofiafaro-da I understand that the change to the spec you suggested would bring it in line with the implementation. The implementation would not stop accepting DARs it has accepted before. Is that correct? If so, then I'm on board.

@sofiafaro-da The implementation will not blow up, because as stated  by @hurryabit the kind `â‹† â†’nat` is uninhabited. Speedy compiler will handle `/\(f : * -> nat). ADD_NUMERIC @(f Unit)` (producing some garbage code), 
but one cannot run this latter, because there exists no `f` of kind  `â‹† â†’nat`

I add 3 tests in #6618 (could you merge it with the current PR):
* One checks that `â‹† â†’nat` is a valid kind
* One checks that `â‹† â†’nat` is inhabited. 
* `/\(f : * -> nat). ADD_NUMERIC @(f Unit)` can be evaluated without blowing up.

We discussed this extensively and came up with a counterexample, where keeping `* -> nat` causes problems in the engine (causes a runtime type error):

```
let g: forall(n:nat). Int64 = /\(n: nat). 1
in /\(f: * -> nat). ADD_INT64 10 (g @(f Unit))
```

Because of the interaction between the erasable kind `* -> nat` and non-erasable kind `nat`. We definitely want to avoid this by outlawing `* -> nat` as I proposed here.

comments.body: In the long run we probably need to distinguish different error classes, such as errors raised via `error`, arithmetic errors, pattern match failures, etc. I would suggest making that the subject of a separate PR though.
I think that can be done easily enough by giving `t` some structure, without really changing most of the semantics.

comments.body: One question that the spec should answer: does it raise a runtime error when inserting a value that is incomparable in an empty map? (I think it should raise an error, for the sake of consistency.)

It does not. 
It raise an exception exactly once `LESS` or `EQUAL` does. 

We agreed with @hurryabit and @hurryabit that is the only semantics that is reasonable. Otherwise you will have to always traverse all the keys to ensure there is no function nested inside. 

Imagine you have the type

``` 
data D = 
    FUN (Int -> Int) 
  | INT Int
```

You can insert `(Fun (\x -> x))` in any `GenMap` that does not content `Fun` variant.
You can also try to lookup the entry of key  `(Fun (\x -> x))` without raising an exception in any `GenMap` that does not content `Fun` variant.

However as soon you have an entry with a key `(Fun ...)` in your map you cannot do anymore any operation  that invole a other key of the form  `(Fun ...)` without raising an exception. 

This choices is simpler and more efficient. Furthermore the compiler will never produce such case.

Ok, if @hurryabit and @hurryabit can confirm ;-) 

The reason I don't like this is that you are creating the potential for latent runtime errors when you perform inserts -- i.e. creating a runtime error that will only be found on a subsequent lookup, instead of when the real error occurs. This is particularly bad for e.g. people using genmaps during testing, or choice validation.

When adding a new key to the map, It should be easy to compare a key to itself using EQUAL, to make sure it doesn't introduce latent runtime errors.
In the proposed semantics, you are only saving 1 comparison, but you are introducing latent runtime errors, so I don't think it's worth it.

It depends on what kind of values you have. If you have ADT-like trees, being able to short circuit on comparisons can make a pretty large difference. Given that we prevent this runtime error in DAML, Iâ€™m not sure that missing out on better performance here in favor of â€œnicer semanticsâ€ for DAML-LF is worth it. That said, I donâ€™t feel particularly strongly about this.

In fact, @associahedron I like your proposal.
The advantage I see, is that we can switch the implementation to hashmap, if we realize the implementation is too slow (we will sorted the map only for serialization). 
 
In other words, in each case (insertion, deletion and lookup) we check the value is equal to itself. Hence we have a nice definition of "comparable" value.

@cocreature If you use nested trees as keys, maps are going to be slow regardless. I'm also not confident that this case will never ever occur at runtime in DAML.

@remyhaemmerle-da ğŸ‘
Alright, then letâ€™s error out for now.

comments.body: Spec should say what happens in the case of empty map lookup of incomparable keys. (I favor more runtime errors.)
At lookup it is not super critical to check the key for self-equality, but I think that at insertion time it is more important.
no error ;)
if you want to leave the possibility for hashtable-based implementation open, you should error on bad lookup keys
As agreed in previous thread, we raise an error

  Get the list of values in the map. The values are returned in the
  order they appear in the map (i.e. sorted by key).

comments.body: Youâ€™re calling this section â€œType orderâ€ and then you start by talking about numeric values. That doesnâ€™t make sense to me.

You are right, this is confusing. 
This section is about *only* type ordering. 
The main difference between type ordering and value ordering is that we need to specify the latter *operationally* to explain how it fails when encounter non comparable values. We do not need an operation specification for the former because the type checker will ensure that comparison of is always defined (the rules for typing ``'to_any'`` and ``'type_rep'``  ensure the type used do not contains variable, quanitifier not type synonyms).


Value ordering is define in the section ``Generic comparison functions``.

comments.body: Maybe Iâ€™m missing something but which rules allows me to deduce that `Int64 < Numeric 10`?

By transitivity (stated in the text)  you have  ``Int64 <â‚œ  Ï„ Ïƒ``  for all ``Ï„`` and ``Ïƒ``.

I replace the text by an explicit rule.
I don't see it @remyhaemmerle-da . There's no rule that lets you infer, for example, that ` Ï„â‚ <â‚œ Ï„â‚‚ Ïƒ` whenever ` Ï„â‚` is not a type application.
Yeah I also cannot find it in the text.

@associahedron 
`TypeOrderStructTyApp` allows you to infer trivially `âŸ¨  âŸ© <â‚œ Ï„â‚‚ Ïƒ`

@moritzkiefer-da Here is how I infer `Int64 < Numeric 10`
- Using `TypeOrderTransitivity`, `TypeOrderInt64Date`, and `TypeOrderDateTimestamp` you can infer that 'Int64' <â‚œ 'Timestamp'.
- Combining with  `TypeOrderTransitivity`, and  `TypeOrderTimestampText` you can infer that  `'Int64' <â‚œ 'Text'`
 ...
- Combining with  `TypeOrderTransitivity`, and  `TypeOrderNatStruct` you can infer that ` 'Int64' <â‚œ âŸ¨  âŸ©`
- Combining with  `TypeOrderTransitivity` and `TypeOrderStructTyApp` you can infer that  `'Int64' <â‚œ Numeric 10`

Oh, I see! That's very hard to see, but it checks out. 

Maybe it would be easier to understand if we used the type rank notion from the scala implementation? We could define a formal type rank function, and then have just one rule for comparing all the types with different type rank.
I do not like to define the rank explicitly (mapping types to integers)
I think it would make the spec match the code more closely, and be easier to understand, which are both better for maintenance, but if you are sure about this way then I'm not opposed.

I want to be able to introduce a new type between two already existing.  
This will oblige me to have different ranks between two specs.

That's fine. The type rank function is entirely formal, and would only exist in the spec, not be exposed in DAML/DAML-LF. Alternatively, you can define a formal enumeration of type ranks (instead of an type rank integer) and use the order from the enumeration.

Anyway, it is up to you.
I did not include the rank.

comments.body: This is fine for the spec, but if we were to actually implement `LESS_EQ` this way it becomes an O(n^2) algorithm. The actual implementation should calculate the relative order of two items (less than, equal, or greater than) in a single step, rather than needing two boolean steps to make the comparison.

This is indeed a spec. The implementation is based on `compare` that return `-1`, `0` or `+1` .
This was a bitter cumbersome to use formally (use the cases 'less than', 'equal to', or 'greater than').
Sounds good ğŸ‘

comments.body: Do you anticipate this situation being possible? I.e. v0 <= v0' is fine but v0' <= v0 leads to error?

I don't. I though it was simpler to specify explicitly this error case, than to prove this never happen.  This would indeed go away with the `compare` function way. I will try once last time to go this way (I abandon twice already).

IMO it's fine if you want to keep the boolean presentation, but change this rule into a note that says that

```
     ğ•†('LESS_EQ' @Ï„â‚ vâ‚€ vâ‚€') = Ok 'True'
      ğ•†('LESS_EQ' @Ï„â‚ vâ‚€' vâ‚€) = Err t
```

cannot happen, and that if it happens, that's a bug.
I simply drop  the rule. I gave up a third time trying to specify with the compare approach.

comments.body: Do we need this to be determined by the ledger? I thought the ledger determines how they are generated but ordering can be specified independent of the ledger.

I changed it to say that contract IDs are ordered by their "internal representation". The spec does not specify the internal representation, so it's the same as saying there is some order, but you can't rely on a specific order.

comments.body:
As for `Any` and `TypeRep`:

* I would like to be able to use `TypeRep` as map keys in DAML triggers. Specifically, the ACS is basically a map indexed by the type of the template. That makes `getContracts` quite efficient. Otherwise, Iâ€™m basically stuck doing a linear search through the whole ACS.
* For things like `dedupCreate` it would be convenient to have a set of create commands which roughly boils down to having a set of `AnyTemplate` so I can do a fast lookup to see if I have to send it again.

So given that this primitive is intended to be used for map keys, it would be great if we could specify an order for this (I donâ€™t care which one).

That said, Iâ€™m totally fine to do this in a separate PR or maybe even as a separate step wtr to the implementation of the spec.

comments.body: As for maps, given that we want to switch to ordered map, can we define the order of a map based on the order of the result of converting it to a list of key-value pairs (orderered by keys)?
That sounds like the best option :)
I added rules for maps. I think cleaning up the spec to get rid of the dependency on insertion order in generic maps should happen in the next PR (if CI ever accepts this one).

comments.body:
This is currently tricky to do in the engine as we do not have enough info at run time.
I was thinking to go lexicographically, but this is definitively better.

I donâ€™t think lexicographic ordering is a reasonable option. The default `Ord` instance in DAML works like the one that @associahedron has used in the spec here and diverging from that is going to cause a lot of confusion.
We probably add an index in the variant and the enum.

~~My mistake. Thanks to catch that~~

The ``[*Available in version ...*]`` in the built-in section are always at the end of the description of the built. That is to say this annotation is about ``EQUAL_CONTRACT_ID`` not ``COERCE_CONTRACT_ID``
Oh I see, I got confused by the diff. LGTM  to me then :+1:

comments.body: Should this be `Ï„[Î±_1 -> Ïƒ_1, â€¦] -> Ïƒ`? Does it make a difference?

Does not make any difference. 
I prefer My notation, as it suggest we can resolve synonym in the body of definition independently of its usage.

I don't think you can resolve the arguments and body independently. 

Example,

```
synonym Foo t = t -> Int64
synonym Bar f = f Int64
```

The rule above would give 
```
Bar Foo â†  Foo Int64
```
But the correct result (obtained from @cocreature's rule) is

```
Bar Foo â†  Int64 -> Int64 
```
Nice example!
We agree with @cocreature that type synonyms are always fully applied. It is not in the ``Bar Foo`` .

Always applied type synonyms should be enough for now, but I don't see a good reason to leave this rule susceptible to the above problems if, in future, we don't guarantee type synonyms are fully applied.

(Also, is it in the spec that type synonyms must be fully applied?)
It should be in the spec but I might have screwed it up :slightly_smiling_face:

The rewriting approach does not really work if type synonym are not fully applied. 
The crux of my spec is that once you applied ``â† `` there is no more type synonym (or if there is still some is that you use an undefined type synonym (or partially applied) in which case the type is not well-formed)
in other terms, `Foo Int64 : *` does not kind check.
I think if we're going down this route we should not be reusing `TApp` in defining type synonyms -- a type synonym application should be considered a separate primitive type operation.
OK.

I think you need to split it out into two cases, in case `Ïƒâ‚` happens to be a partially applied synonym.

```
 Ï„â‚  â†   Ïƒâ‚        Ï„â‚‚  â†   Ïƒâ‚‚

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” RewriteApp1

Ïƒâ‚ Ïƒâ‚‚ â†  Ïƒ 
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” RewriteApp2
    Ï„â‚ Ï„â‚‚  â†   Ïƒ
```
Wonâ€™t we already all in the `RewriteSynonym` case for `RewriteApp2` here?

Not if `Ïƒâ‚` is a partially applied type synonym. Of course, that can't happen if type synonyms must be fully applied in every case.

Concrete example:

```
synonym Foo a b = a -> b 
synonym Bar = Foo Int64
```

then `Bar Int64 ` doesn't fall into either `RewriteSynonym` or `RewriteApp1`, you would need `RewriteApp2` to make progress with `Bar â†  Foo Int64` before getting `Bar Int64 â†  Int64 -> Int64`.

comments.body: I think it would be good to point out explicitly that this is sensitive to insertion order. This seems like something that might trip people up.

The generic equality for genmap should not be sensitive to insertion order. This is what we agreed before and this is how equality for genmaps has been implemented in general.

This rule here is not correct.

A fixed version of the rule might be the following three statements in first-order logic (all three are necessary, although the third could be combined with either of the first two):

- forall i in 1 .. m  there exists a unique j in 1 .. n such that v_i ~ v'_j
- forall j in 1 .. n there exists a unique i in 1 .. m such that v_i ~ v'_j
- forall i in 1 .. m, forall j in 1 .. n, if v_i ~ v'_j then w_i ~ w'_j

The "unique" in "exists a unique" prevents the consideration of maps that have repeated keys, which is fine.
Ah, I see the rule here is *not sensitive* to insertion order, which is good. It's not very easy to see. (-:
Oh thanks, I got confused by all the indices.
I had a comment to underline the underline the equality of generic map is not sensitive to order of entries.

comments.body:
When did we decide to do this? I'm not convinced requiring the submitter of a `fetchByKey` to be a maintainer of the key is a good idea. This definitely hurts the compositionality of workflows. I also don't see the technical necessity of this change. Being a stakeholder of the contract should absolutely be enough. If you know a contract with the right key exists, then it must be the unique contract with this key. If you don't see a contract with such a key, you can't submit the transaction anyway. (I'm not talking about `lookupByKey` here!)

cc @bame-da @gerolf-da
In fact, this restriction is pretty much against the spirit of https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/issues/2311, which we all seem to have agreed on.
This is not recent. This was done by francesco. See #1866 already referenced in #2311.
I just moved the comment from line 227/232 to line 246/252

+versions >= 1.6*], all fields with suffix ``_interned_str`` are
+[*Available in versions >= 1.dev*].  The deserialization process will
+reject any DAML-LF 1.dev (or latter) that that does not comply this
+restriction.

+..............

+in a global table and referenced by their index.

+identifiers`. Such message is interpreted as the name built from the
+sequence the interned identifiers it contains.  The field

+so-called `interned name` is a valid zero-based index of this list. An
+`interned names` is interpreted as the name built form the `name` it

comments.body: Do we want to allow contract ids? The absolute vs relative thing makes that a bit dangerous so at least on the DAML level I probably wouldnâ€™t expose it.

Contract IDs are fine here as long as we stick to the following two assumptions:
(1) the rewriting from relative to absolute IDs is injective and no relative ID is ever rewritten to an absolute ID that is in use already,
(2) the rewriting of all contract IDs in a transaction happens in one go without any map operations performed in the middle.
I wonder if we should document these assumptions (in better words than mine)?
Oh I see, I think I didnâ€™t realize how the rewriting works until now. Makes sense now but yeah we should definitely document this imho.

comments.body: We should specify how this affects the "order in which keys were inserted" which is relevant for the conversion to lists, do we first-inserted-order or last-inserted-order? If we go with the former, the latter can be _efficiently_ expressed in terms of the former (and `GENMAP_DELETE`). I don't see how this would be possible _efficiently_ the other way around.
I am inclined toward  `last-inserted-order`.

I think first inserted order makes more sense. It's certainly what I meant in the spec. It implies that if you insert the same (key, value) pair in a map that is already there, it will not modify the map, i.e. inserts are idempotent. That's nice.

I don't know what you mean _exactly_ by "inserts are idempotent". I assume you mean
```
insert k v . insert k v  ==  insert k v
```
for all `k` and `v`. This is true for last-inserted order as well. I think what is more compelling about first-inserted order is that we get
```
insert k (lookup k m) m  ==  m
```
for all `m` and keys `k` of `m`.

We can also define
```
insertLast k v = insertFirst k v . delete k
```
Thus, insert-first order is at least as "powerful" as insert-last order.
Ah, you're right. My sentence was better before the `i.e.`.

comments.body:
You are forgetting the "nice" case where keys are maps. 
Of course we can a first implementation without map keys.

That's not nice! We probably will need to add them, but I'm worried the "insertion order" issue will mess people up.

But also I don't see map values under the values section (including `'Map'`). Probably should add them?
We can postpone this problem for later.

TextMap (simply called 'Map' in the spec) are not concern with the insertion order.
They are sorted by key when converted to list or serialized in the ledger.

Right. I propose that two `'Map'` (i.e. TextMap) are considered equal if they have the same key-value pairs, and two `'GenMap'` are considered equal if they have the same key-value pairs *in the same insertion order*, so they result in the same output when using `GENMAP_KEYS` and `GENMAP_VALUES`.

(We could make the insertion order irrelevant for map key comparison, but then two "equal keys" could result in different outputs when passed through `GENMAP_KEYS`. Furthermore, the equality instance `(Eq a, Eq b) => Eq (GenMap a b)` that will be defined in DAML, in terms of `GENMAP_KEYS` and `GENMAP_VALUES`, is sensitive to insertion order, so it makes sense to make key comparison sensitive to that as well.)
Following discussion with @bame-da, we decided that equality for GenMaps should not consider insertion order.

Are we planning to add a builtin `GENMAP_EQ : forall k v. (v -> v -> Bool) -> GenMap k v -> GenMap k v -> Bool`? (I assume we need to use the builtin equality for keys to make this work. I'm slowly starting to despise user-defined equality...)

We were not planning to add this function as it was not here for `TextMap`. 

But I am planning to add a generic equality `EQUAL: forall v. v -> v -> Bool` using the builin equality. This will obviously work with `GenMap`. Is it not enough ?

@remyhaemmerle-da The issue is that `Eq` (the DAML typeclass) does not necessarily match the built-in equality, so you may get unexpected results when using something like `EQUAL`. In any case we can define `GENMAP_EQ` in Daml without problem, it just won't be fast.
@hurryabit Could we remove user-defined equality from DAML? Should we?
OK. Let's start without it. We can still add it letter.
@hurryabit I think we can outlaw custom `Eq` instances in the preprocessor, and tell users to use `deriving Eq` instead.
We could make it a warning for a while, and turn it into an outright error later.
That sounds reasonable to me. We should then also replace the derived `Eq` instances with calls to our DAML-LF primitive during our conversion to DAML-LF.

comments.body: @hurryabit Do we want to get ride of tuples ?
If so, we could have separate `GENMAP_KEYS` and `GENMAP_VALUES` . All I did was copy the existing operations from `'Map'`.

IIRC, we had considered this for `TextMap` already but then decided against having `keys` and `values` separately. Unfortunately, I can't remember why. Doing the zipping in DAML land seems reasonable. If we go with the structural records, we would need to map them into proper DAML pairs anyway. Thus, the performance characteristics don't differ too much. Let's go with `GENMAP_KEYS` and `GENMAP_VALUES`.

+* ``GENMAP_LOOKUP : âˆ€ Î±. âˆ€ Î².  Î± â†’ 'GenMap' Î± Î² â†’ 'Optional' Î±``
+

+
+* ``GENMAP_DELETE : âˆ€ Î±. âˆ€ Î².  Î± â†’ 'GenMap' Î± Î² â†’ 'GenMap' Î± Î²``

Naive question. 
 Why not `'to_any' @Ï„ : Ï„ -> Any` instead of `'to_any' @Ï„ e: Any`  ?

Two reasons:
1. For `to_any`, you would end up with applications sometimes being values if the function is `to_any Ï„` which is a bit awkward. This does not apply to `from_any`.
2. Consistency: Changing only `from_any` while keeping `to_any` the way it is due to 1 feels weird and also doesnâ€™t fit in with things like `Cons`, `create`, â€¦ that are all defined similarly.

+Nat kind and Nat types
+......................
+
+[*Available since version 1.dev*]
+
+The deserialization process will reject any DAML-LF 1.6 (or earlier)
+that uses ``nat`` field in ``Kind`` or ``Type`` messages.
+
+Starting from DAML-LF 1.dev those messages are deserialized to ``nat``
+kind and ``nat`` type respectively. The field ``nat`` of ``Type``
+message must be a positive integer.
+
+Note that despite their is no concrete way to build Nat types in a
+DAML-LF 1.6 (or earlier) program, those are implicitly generated when
+reading as Numeric type and Numeric builtin as described in the next
+section.
+
